item.title: project_one
item.description:
Introduction

Snowshoe hares, Lepus americanus, can be found in boreal and upper montane forests across North America. Snowshoe hares are primarily herbivorous, eating a variety of flowers, grasses, and plants. In Alaska, hares depend more heavily on grasses and leaves in the summer months, and twigs and bark during the winter. This project aims to explore the seasonal weight distributions of snowhoe hare populations living throughout the Tanana valley in Alaska (Department of Fish and Game).

knitr::include_graphics('/images/picture.jpg')

Snowshoe hares have adapted to blend in with their surroundings by seasonally changing their coat colors.

Credit: Denali National Park and Preserve

Data and Methods

Data for snowshoe hare weights, measured in grams, from 1999-2012 collected and provided by Bonanza Creek LTER research team. Hare measurements obtained from capture-recapture studies across 5 locations in the Tanana valley. For more information on data collection procedures, and the project as a whole, see metadata. Data from September, October, and November have been grouped together under “fall”, March, April, and May have been grouped under “spring”, and June, July, and August have been grouped under “Summer”. We did not compare data from the winter months due to a deficit in data collected during this time. Additionally, observations without clear age or gender measurements were removed. All figures were prepared using R software version 3.6.1.

!

knitr::include_graphics('/images/map.jpg')

Snowshoe hare capture-recapture studies occured along the Tanana River and throughout the Bonanza Experimental Research Forest.

Credit: Long Term Ecological Research Network

# attach packages and read in data
library(tidyverse)
library(purrr)
library(dplyr)
library(lubridate)
library(tidyr)
library(car)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(effsize)
library(kableExtra)
library(janitor)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(broom)
hare <- read_csv(("showshoe_lter.csv"), na= "0")

Results

# select data I'm interested in working with (adult males) and drop na values
hare_am <- hare %>% 
  select(date, weight, age, sex) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  filter(age == "a"| age == "A") %>% 
  filter(sex == "m"| sex == "M")
# specify dates just by month
hare_month <- hare_am %>% 
  mutate(date_new = lubridate::mdy(date)) %>% 
  mutate(month = lubridate::month(date_new, label = TRUE)) %>% 
  select(weight, month) 
# sort data by seasons
hare_seasons<- hare_month %>% 
  mutate(season = dplyr::case_when(month %in% c("Jan", "Feb", "Dec") ~ "winter",
                   month %in% c("Sep", "Oct", "Nov") ~ "fall",
                   month  %in% c("Jun", "Jul", "Aug") ~ "summer",
                   month  %in% c("Mar", "Apr", "May") ~ "spring")) %>% 
  select(weight, season)
# calculate summary statistics
hare_summary <- hare_seasons %>% 
  group_by(season) %>% 
  summarize(mean_weight = round(mean(weight),1),
            median= round(median(weight),1),
            sd_weight = round(sd(weight),1),
            sample_n = n(),
            se_weight = round(sd(weight, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(n()),1),
            var_weight = var(weight, na.rm = TRUE))
# make graph visualizing adult male snowshoe hare weights by season and customize
ggplot()+
geom_beeswarm (data = hare_seasons, aes(x = season, y = weight), size = 1, alpha = .5,pch = 16, color = "#4D6483")+
scale_x_discrete (labels = c("Fall", "Spring", "Summer", "Winter"))+
labs(x = "Season", y = " Weight (Grams)", title = "Snowshoe Hare Weights by Season \n Adult Males (1999-2012)")+
geom_point(data = hare_summary, aes(x=season, y= mean_weight), color = "maroon", size = 2.5)+
geom_point(data = hare_summary, aes(x=season, y= median), color = "blue", size = 1.5, alpha = .7)+
geom_errorbar(data = hare_summary, 
                aes(x = season, 
                    ymin = mean_weight - sd_weight,
                    ymax = mean_weight + sd_weight),
                color = "#612F62",
                width = 0.09) +
  theme_light()+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))+
  scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0,2250), breaks = seq(0,2250, by=250), expand = c(0,0))+
  theme(panel.background = element_rect(colour = "black", size=1))+
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank())

Figure 1: Seasonal weight differences, excluding Winter, in adult male Snowshoe hares (1999-2012). Gray points indicate individual hare weights, measured in grams. Maroon points indicate sample means, and error bars indicate ± standard deviation. Median sample weights are indicated by smaller blue points. Data Source: Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present

Table 1: Adult male snowshoe hare size metrics

# make table of summary statistics (grouped by season)
hare_table <-hare_summary %>% 
  select(-se_weight) %>% 
  select(-var_weight)

  hare_table %>% 
    kable(col.names = c("Season", 
                      "Mean Weight (grams)",
                      "Median Weight (grams)",
                      "Standard Deviation",
                      "Sample Size")) %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "bordered", 
                full_width = F,
                position = "left") %>% 
  row_spec(1, background = "#C3C7CC") %>% 
  row_spec(3, background = "#C3C7CC") %>% 
  row_spec(2, background = "#F1F2F3")
Season Mean Weight (grams) Median Weight (grams) Standard Deviation Sample Size
fall 1588.4 1620 134.9 92
spring 1492.6 1500 110.4 55
summer 1372.4 1350 213.5 151

The average mean and median weights of adult male snowshoe hares differ seasonally. Data collected during the fall, spring, and summer months illustrate that on average, adult male hares are the heaviest in fall and weigh the least throughout summer (Figure 1). These trends hold true for both mean and median weight measurements. On average, adult male hares weigh 95.8 grams more in the fall than in the spring, and 216 grams more in the fall than in the summer based on mean measurements. Median weights differ by 120 grams between fall and spring, and 270 grams between fall and summer (Table 1).

References

Alaska Department of Fish and Game “Snowshoe Hare Species Profile, Alaska Department of Fish and Game.” Snowshoe Hare (Lepus Americanus), www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=snowshoehare.main.

Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14.

item.title: project_three
item.description:
Introduction

This project explores Steelhead fish use of the Bonneville Dam. Steelhead Trout are a migratory fish species, often migrating between the ocean and freshwater sources many times throughout their life. Steelhead trout are born in freshwater and migrate to the ocean before reaching adulthood. Later in life, these fish will migrate up the same river in which they were born to spawn (FWS). Human disturbances to the natural ecosystem, including the creation and modification of dams, are one of the many threats to Steelhead populations (Center for Biological Diversity). The Bonneville dam, located between Oregon and Washington, is complete with a 70 foot fish ladder which allows for the safe passage of fish through the dam (Northwest Power and Conservation Council). This project explores the daily, monthly, and annual counts of Steelhead Trout observed passing through the Bonneville dam from 1939-2019. Data provided by Columbia River Research.

knitr::include_graphics('/images/Rainbow_trout.png')

Credit: Duane Raver

Results

# Attach libraries and read in data
library(tidyverse)
## ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ──
## ✓ ggplot2 3.2.1     ✓ purrr   0.3.3
## ✓ tibble  2.1.3     ✓ dplyr   0.8.4
## ✓ tidyr   1.0.0     ✓ stringr 1.4.0
## ✓ readr   1.3.1     ✓ forcats 0.4.0
## ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
## x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
library(tsibble)
## 
## Attaching package: 'tsibble'
## The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':
## 
##     id
library(fable)
## Loading required package: fabletools
library(fabletools)
library(feasts)
library(forecast)
## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod':
##   method            from
##   as.zoo.data.frame zoo
## Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'forecast':
##   method             from    
##   fitted.fracdiff    fracdiff
##   residuals.fracdiff fracdiff
## 
## Attaching package: 'forecast'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:fabletools':
## 
##     GeomForecast, StatForecast
library(janitor)
## 
## Attaching package: 'janitor'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     chisq.test, fisher.test
steelhead <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv")
## Parsed with column specification:
## cols(
##   year = col_double(),
##   `mm-dd` = col_character(),
##   location = col_character(),
##   parameter = col_character(),
##   unit = col_character(),
##   datatype = col_character(),
##   value = col_double()
## )
# wrangle to get dates in various formats
steelhead_date <- steelhead %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  separate(mm_dd, into = c("day","month_abb"), sep = "-") %>% 
  mutate (month = match(month_abb,month.abb)) 

steelhead_date$new_date <-lubridate::ymd(paste(steelhead_date$year, steelhead_date$month, steelhead_date$day, sep="-")) 
## Warning: 61 failed to parse.
steelhead_date_2 <- steelhead_date %>%
  drop_na(new_date, value) %>% 
  mutate(month_sep = yearmonth(new_date)) %>% 
  mutate(value = as.numeric(value)) %>% 
  drop_na(month_sep, value) %>% 
  mutate(month_new = lubridate::month(new_date, label = TRUE))

# view(steelhead_date_2)

steelhead_mmdd <- steelhead %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  rename(month_date = mm_dd)

steelhead_final <- steelhead_date_2 %>% 
  select(location:value,new_date:month_new) %>% 
  mutate(year = lubridate::year(new_date))
# ONE: Time series of original observations (daily)
ggplot(data = steelhead_final, aes(x = new_date, y = value)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue")+
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x = "Date", y = "Daily Fish Counts", title = "Daily Steelhead Passage \n Through the Bonneville Dam (1939-2019)") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))

Figure 1: Daily Steelhead Trout counts at the Bonneville Dam. Daily observations obtains from January 1st, 1939 through December 31st, 2019. Data: Columbia River Research.

Large daily variations in Steelhead Trout counts exist at the Bonneville Dam between 1939-2019. The highest daily recorded fish count was 34,053 fish in one day, while no fish were observed on other days.

# TWO: Time series of seasonplot (monthly)
steelhead_monthly <- steelhead_final %>% 
  group_by(month_new, year) %>% 
  summarize(month_sum = sum(value))

ggplot(steelhead_monthly, aes(x = month_new, y = month_sum, group = year)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = year)) +
  labs(x = "Month", y = "Monthly Fish Counts", title ="Total Monthly Steelhead Passage \n Through the Bonneville Dam (by Year)")+
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))+
  scale_color_gradient(low='#66D367', high='#4371CC')

Figure 2: Monthly Steelhead Trout counts at the Bonneville Dam. Fish counts obtained daily and totaled together to obtain monthly counts. Earlier observations represented by green lines, while later years are in blue. Data: Columbia River Research

Observations of Steelhead Trout populations at the Bonneville dam appear to follow similar monthly trends across the years. While very few fish are observed between January-May and October-November, fish counts have drastically increased during June-September months during all recorded years. It appears that monthly fish counts are greatest in August, possibly suggesting yearly migration patterns.

# THREE: Time series of annual steelhead counts


steelhead_annual <- steelhead_final %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(annual_sum = sum(value))

# using tsibble:
# annual_ts <- as_tsibble(steelhead_annual, index = year)
# annual_ts %>% autoplot(annual_sum) # I'll graph in ggplot instead
# annual_ts %>% gg_subseries(annual_sum) # does not work
# annual_ts %>% gg_season(annual_sum) # does not work

ggplot(data = steelhead_annual, aes(x = year, y = annual_sum)) +
  geom_line(color = "maroon") +
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Annual Fish Counts", title = "Total Annual Steelhead Passage \n Through the Bonneville Dam")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))+
  scale_color_gradient(low='#6CE98E', high='#5072DF')+
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)

Figure 3: Annual Steelhead Trout counts at the Bonneville Dam. Yearly totals obtained from 1939-2019. Data: Columbia River Research

It appears that while there are significant yearly fluctuations in Steelhead Trout populations traveling through the Bonneville dam, annual Steelhead Trout counts are generally increasing over time. Most notable, very large increases in Steelhead Trout populations were observed in 2001 and 2009. These dramatic increases were rapidly followed by a decline in fish by the following year.

References

Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text

“Dams: Impacts on Salmon and Steelhead.” Northwest Power and Conservation Council, www.nwcouncil.org/reports/columbia-river-history/damsimpacts.

“Natural History: CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST STEELHEAD TROUT.” Center for Biological Diversity, www.biologicaldiversity.org/species/fish/central_California_coast_steelhead_trout/natural_history.html.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service/Fish and Aquatic Conservation. “Steelhead Trout.” Official Web Page of the U S Fish and Wildlife Service, www.fws.gov/fisheries/fishmigration/steelhead_trout.html.

item.title: project_two
item.description:
knitr::include_graphics('/images/fastfood.jpg')

Credit: freepik

Introduction

This report explores the relationship between nutrients present in sampled fast foods. The nutritional content of 371 common fast food items were analyzed, using 11 common nutritional measures for comparison. This report will explore which nutrients, if any, were positively and negatively correlated to one another. Data for this project provided USDA (National Nutrient Database), now FoodData Central

# read in data and attach packages
library(tidyverse)
## ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ──
## ✓ ggplot2 3.2.1     ✓ purrr   0.3.3
## ✓ tibble  2.1.3     ✓ dplyr   0.8.4
## ✓ tidyr   1.0.0     ✓ stringr 1.4.0
## ✓ readr   1.3.1     ✓ forcats 0.4.0
## ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
## x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
library(janitor)
## 
## Attaching package: 'janitor'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     chisq.test, fisher.test
library(ggfortify)

food <- read_csv("usda_nutrients.csv") %>% 
  clean_names() 
## Parsed with column specification:
## cols(
##   .default = col_double(),
##   FoodGroup = col_character(),
##   ShortDescrip = col_character(),
##   Descrip = col_character(),
##   CommonName = col_character(),
##   MfgName = col_character(),
##   ScientificName = col_character()
## )
## See spec(...) for full column specifications.
#Select data of interest, drop na values, rename columes
food_filtered <- food %>% 
  filter(food_group == "Fast Foods") %>% 
  select(protein_g: fiber_g, energy_kcal, vit_a_mcg:vit_e_mg) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  rename(Energy = energy_kcal) %>% 
  rename(Protein = protein_g) %>% 
  rename(Fat = fat_g) %>% 
  rename(Carbohydrates = carb_g) %>% 
  rename(Sugar = sugar_g) %>% 
  rename(Fiber = fiber_g) %>% 
  rename(VitA = vit_a_mcg) %>% 
  rename(VitB6 = vit_b6_mg) %>% 
  rename(VitB12 = vit_b12_mcg) %>% 
  rename(VitC = vit_c_mg) %>% 
  rename(VitE = vit_e_mg)  
# Run principal component analysis on selected variables
food_pca <- prcomp(food_filtered, scale = TRUE)
#summary(food_pca)

#plot(food_pca)
#biplot(food_pca)
# Create a biplot of results and add customizations
food_biplot <- autoplot(food_pca, 
                      colour = NA,
                      loadings.label = TRUE,
                      loadings.label.size = 3,
                      loadings.label.colour = "black",
                      loadings.colour='maroon',
                      loadings.label.repel = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x= "Principal Component 1", y = "Principal Component 2", title = "Fast Food Nutrition")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))
food_biplot
## Warning: Removed 371 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

Figure 1: Principal component analysis: fast food nutritional content. Analyis performed on 371 common fast food items. Smaller angles between variables (maroon arrows) indicate highly correlated nutrients, such as carbohydrates and fiber. Variance of the variables are represented by arrow length, with longer lengths representing larger variances.

Summary

  • Carbohydrates and fiber in fast foods are highly positively correlated. Protein, vitamin B12 and vitamin B6 appear to be positively correlated as well.

  • Protein and sugar in fast foods are negatively correlated (as one increases, the other decreases).

  • Many components of fast foods appear to be uncorrelated, including vtiamin E and protein, energy and vitamin B12, fiber and fat, and sugar and vitamin E.
